issues.text: The only question that has been urged before us is whether the suit is competent.

anchor.surface_text: From the last order the present appeal has been filed by special leave of this Court. The only question that has been urged before us is whether the suit is competent.

issues.text: The question which is raised in this appeal is whether after this was done, the suit which was still pending could continue before the Munsif and on the application under the U.P. Agriculturist Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule 2 List I of the Abolition Act conferred jurisdiction on Assistant Collectors First Class to eject asamis. The question which is raised in this appeal is whether after this was done, the suit which was still pending. could continue before the Munsif and on the application under the U.P. Agriculturist Relief Act.

issues.text: We have, therefore, to consider in this appeal what was the status of the representatives of the mortgagor on the one hand and of the mortgagee on the other, and then to decide whether the Munsif was competent to pass the decree for redemption and to order the ejectment of the present appellants.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, to consider in this appeal what was the status of the representatives of the mortgagor on the one hand and of the mortgagee on the other, and then to decide whether the Munsif was competent to pass the decree for redemption and to order the ejectment of the present appellants.

issues.text: the main point which was urged before the appellate Court was that as the U.P. Agriculturist Relief Act was repealed by an Act in 1953 which amended the Abolition Act, the suit under s. 12 of the U.P. Agriculturist Relief Act was rendered incompetent

anchor.surface_text: All the above findings were confirmed by the Civil Judge, Allahabad who disposed of the appeal. The main point which was urged before the appellate Court was that as the U.P. Agriculturist Relief Act was repealed by an Act in 1953 which amended the Abolition Act, the suit under s. 12 of the U.P. Agriculturist Relief Act was rendered incompetent and the plaintiffs could not eject the representatives of the mortgagee except in accordance with the provisions of the Abolition Act.

holdings.text: the proceedings before the Munsif were with jurisdiction because they were not affected by the passing of the Abolition Act or the amending Act, 1953, regard being had to the provisions of s. 6 of the U.P. General Clauses Act in the first instance and more so in view of the provisions of s. 23 of the amending Act, 1956 which came before the proceedings between the parties had finally terminated.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit filed prior to repeal and Abolition Act enforcement; S.6 U.P. General Clauses Act preserves pending proceedings absent contrary intent; reinforced by explicit saving in S.23 U.P. Act XVIII 1956 applicable even at appellate stage.

holdings.text: unless a different intention appears, the repeal shall not affect any investigation or legal proceeding commenced before the repealing Act shall have come into operation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of S.6 U.P. General Clauses Act to pending suit under U.P. Agriculturist Relief Act; repeal does not abate proceedings started before.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the Abolition Act which takes away the right of suit in respect of a pending action. ... there is no provision in the Abolition Act that pending cases were to stand transferred to the Assistant Collector for disposal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of express provision ousting jurisdiction or transferring pending cases indicates no contrary intention to S.6 General Clauses Act.

holdings.text: S. 23 of the amending Act of 1956 created a special saving ... any proceeding instituted or commenced before any court or authority prior to the commencement of this Act shall, notwithstanding any amendment herein made, continue to be heard and decided by such court or authority.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit saving clause confirms pending proceedings continue under pre-amendment law, applicable to suit pending in appeal when Act passed.

holdings.text: the provisions of S. 14(2)(a) exclude a mortgagee with possession from claiming [sirdar] right in respect of such land [sir or khudkasht of the mortgagor].

anchor.surface_text: The learned Munsif pointed out that, even though the representatives of the mortgagee had obtained a certificate as Sirdars, they could not enjoy that status, in view of s. 14 (2) (a). The claim that the appellants became the Sirdars of this land is abandoned before us because the land was the Sir Sankalap of the mortgagor and the provisions of S. 14 (2) (a) exclude a mortgagee with Possession from claiming that right in respect of such land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory deeming under S.14(2)(a) U.P. ZALRA: land remains sir of mortgagor despite mortgagee possession and certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Munsif pointed out that, even though the representatives of the mortgagee had obtained a certificate as Sirdars, they could not enjoy that status, in view of s. 14 (2) (a). The claim that the appellants became the Sirdars of this land is abandoned before us because the land was the Sir Sankalap of the mortgagor and the provisions of S. 14 (2) (a) exclude a mortgagee with Possession from claiming that right in respect of such land.
